abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Health Sector
            Development Project for Sri Lanka were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory; the risk to development
            outcome was moderate; the Bank's performance was
            moderately satisfactory; and the Borrower's performance
            was also moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: decentralized health services work best when roles
            and responsibilities are clear, the central level fulfills
            its stewardship functions, and the decentralized levels are
            provided with adequate resources. In order to avoid
            disbursement delays, where there are many implementing
            agencies, special account reimbursements should not depend
            on consolidation of Interim Unaudited Financial Reports
            (IUFR) from all agencies. Piecemeal and fragmented
            implementation of civil works could have been avoided by
            development of a proper procurement master plan for works
            and a health infrastructure development master plan. While
            bed occupancy can provide a crude measure of efficiency for
            utilization of hospitals, it may be inappropriate for
            comparing hospitals of different capacities and levels.
